importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the publication date of the article, indicating the most recent update on the flooding crisis in Mexico.
The date marks when the death toll was officially reported at 64, with ongoing updates on missing persons and recovery efforts.
The daily news briefing on this date includes updated figures on casualties, missing individuals, and relief operations.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding occurred during a recent period of heavy rainfall, affecting five Mexican states over the previous week.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded on Wednesday in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso, triggering severe flooding.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died due to flooding caused by heavy rains in five Mexican states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, confirmed 65 people are still missing.
The states most affected are Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), Puebla (13 deaths), and Queretaro (1 death).
Over 100,000 houses have been impacted, with some homes near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
The flooding was linked to the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which caused rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (280mm) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (286mm).
Thousands of military personnel from the Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to deliver food, water, and medical aid.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply to the affected areas, where 263,000 users lost power.
Governors and national authorities are coordinating response efforts across the affected states.
Mexico’s meteorological alert system was criticized for failing to issue warnings about the extreme rainfall magnitude.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Severe flooding in Mexico, triggered by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, has resulted in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The hardest-hit states are Veracruz, Hidalgo, and Puebla, with the heaviest rainfall recorded in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso. The National Civil Protection Coordination, under the leadership of Laura Velazquez Alzua, coordinated emergency responses, while President Claudia Sheinbaum emphasized the failure of early meteorological warnings. Thousands of military personnel and nearly 400 repair workers have been deployed to provide aid, distribute clean water, and restore electricity to over 263,000 affected users. The disaster highlights both the vulnerability of coastal and inland communities to extreme weather events and the importance of early climate forecasting.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
